sub_topic: Finding the angle of elevation or depression
message_1: A student is standing 200 meters away from the foot of a building. The angle of elevation from the student's eye to the top of the building is 30 degrees. What is the height of the building?
message_2:
To find the height of the building, we can use the tangent function in trigonometry. The tangent of an angle in a right triangle is the ratio of the length of the side opposite the angle to the length of the side adjacent to the angle.

In this problem, we have the angle of elevation (30 degrees) and the distance from the student to the building (200 meters). We can set up the equation:

tan(angle) = height / distance

Plugging in the given values:

tan(30) = height / 200

The tangent of 30 degrees is equal to 1/sqrt(3) or sqrt(3)/3. So,

sqrt(3)/3 = height / 200

To find the height, multiply both sides by 200:

height = 200 * sqrt(3)/3

The height of the building is approximately 115.47 meters.
